{{About|the left-wing charter created in 2009||People's Charter (disambiguation){{!}}People's Charter|other uses}} {{Infobox document | document_name = The People's Charter | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | orig_lang_code = | title_orig = | date_created = September 2009 | date_presented = | date_ratified = | date_effective = | date_repeal = | location_of_document = [[United Kingdom]] | commissioned = | writer = A commission of British [[Trade unions in the United Kingdom|trade unionists]] | signers = See: [[The People's Charter (21st century)#Endorsements|Endorsements section]] | media_type = | subject = | purpose = Uniting the [[British Left]] and providing an alternative to the [[neoliberal]] political agenda }} '''The People's Charter''' was a campaigning document in the [[United Kingdom]] devised by a commission of [[Trade unions in the United Kingdom|trade unionists]] with the intention of uniting the [[British Left|left]] and providing an alternative to the [[neoliberal]] political agenda.<ref name="Morning_Star">{{cite news | last = Richards | first = Andy | title = A people’s alternative | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120511023708/http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/index.php/news/content/view/full/90816 | archive-date = 11 May 2012 | url = http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/index.php/news/content/view/full/90816 | work = [[Morning Star (British newspaper)|Morning Star]] | date = 26 May 2010 |access-date = 24 June 2010}}</ref> The Charter demands public control of the banks, along with energy, water and transport, ensuring that there is investment in these services instead of money being creamed off to corporate shareholders. It also calls for a [[Progressive tax|fairer tax system]], with the wealthy and big business paying their way, investment not cuts in public services, the creation of millions of new homes, and sustainable jobs with decent wages.<ref>{{cite book | title = The People's Charter for a fairer Scotland | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161129082623/http://www.unison-scotland.org.uk/peoplescharter/PeoplesCharter.pdf | archive-date = 29 November 2016 | url = http://www.unison-scotland.org.uk/peoplescharter/PeoplesCharter.pdf | publisher = Scottish Organising Committee for the People's Charter | year = 2009 | access-date = 28 November 2016 }}</ref>
==Points covered by the Charter== Using the six demands of the ''[[People's Charter of 1838]]'' as a template,<ref name="Morning_Star" /> the demands of the People's Charter are:
# A fair economy for a fairer Britain # More and better jobs # Decent homes for all # Save and improve our services # Fairness and Justice # A better future starts now
==Endorsements== The People's Charter has been endorsed by the following Trade Unions: the [[National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers|RMT]], the [[Communication Workers Union (UK)|CWU]], the [[Fire Brigades Union|FBU]], the [[Public and Commercial Services Union|PCS]], the [[National Union of Teachers|NUT]], the [[NUJ]], the [[BFAWU]] POA (Scotland), the [[University and College Union|UCU]], and the [[Trades Union Congress|TUC]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Congress Decisions 2009, Resolutions Carried: 32 People's Charter | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101214102025/http://www.tuc.org.uk/the_tuc/tuc-17093-f0.cfm | archive-date = 14 December 2010 | url = http://www.tuc.org.uk/congress/tuc-17255-f18.cfm | publisher = [[Trades Union Congress]] | access-date = 24 June 2010 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref>
The People's Charter attracted support from various high-profile politicians including [[Jeremy Corbyn]], [[Tony Benn]] and [[John McDonnell]], and a number of personalities from the arts world including [[Billy Bragg]], [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]], [[Mark Thomas]] and [[Ken Loach]].<ref>{{cite book | title = The People's Charter a charter for change | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180526132427/http://www.plymouth-tuc.co.uk/Website/Resources/People's%20Charter.pdf |archive-date = 26 May 2018 |url= http://www.plymouth-tuc.co.uk/Website/Resources/People's%20Charter.pdf | publisher = Plymouth TUC | year = 2009 | access-date = 28 November 2016 }}</ref>
It has also been endorsed by the [[Communist Party of Britain]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://communist-party.org.uk/britain/peoples-assembly/745-peoples-charter-getting-organised-locally.html|title=People's Charter - getting organised locally|website=communist-party.org.uk|publisher=[[Communist Party of Britain]] |date = 13 February 2010}}</ref> [[Labour Representation Committee (2004)|Labour Representation Committee]],<ref>{{cite web | title = People’s Charter Convention - Sat 21 Nov | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120303035942/http://l-r-c.org.uk/news/story/peoples-charter-convention-sat-21-nov/ |archive-date = 3 March 2012 |url= http://l-r-c.org.uk/news/story/peoples-charter-convention-sat-21-nov/ | website = l-r-c.org.uk | publisher = [[Labour Representation Committee (2004)|Labour Representation Committee]] |date = 20 November 2009|access-date = 25 June 2010}}</ref> the Scottish [[Campaign for Socialism]],<ref>{{cite web | last =Campaign for Socialism Exec | author-link = Campaign for Socialism | title = Launch of Scottish Labour Representation Committee and People’s Charter|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216204130/http://www.thecitizen.org.uk/?p=110 |archive-date = 16 February 2012|url= http://www.thecitizen.org.uk/?p=110|website=www.thecitizen.org.uk |date = 23 February 2009}}</ref> and the [[Socialist Party (England and Wales)|Socialist Party]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Sell | first = Hannah | title = Is the People’s Charter a step towards workers’ political representation? | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180526140715/http://socialistpartyscotland.org.uk/2009/11/26/is-the-peoples-charter-a-step-towards-workers-political-representation/ |archive-date = 26 May 2018 | url = http://socialistpartyscotland.org.uk/2009/11/26/is-the-peoples-charter-a-step-towards-workers-political-representation/ | website = socialistpartyscotland.org.uk | publisher = [[Socialist Party Scotland]] | date = 26 November 2009 |access-date = 26 May 2018}}</ref>
==Criticisms== The People's Charter has been criticised by some parties on the left, particularly [[Alliance for Workers' Liberty|Workers' Liberty]], for being too limited in its scope, and for being [[social democratic]] rather than [[Revolutionary socialism|revolutionary]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Saddiq | first = Amina | title = The problem with the "People's Charter" | url = http://www.workersliberty.org/story/2009/02/21/problem-peoples-charter | website = workersliberty.org | publisher = [[Alliance for Workers' Liberty|Workers' Liberty]] | date = 21 February 2009 |access-date = 24 June 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite news | last = McDonnell | first = John | author-link = John McDonnell | title = Time for a new People's Charter | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/mar/09/protest-recession | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 9 March 2009}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140203093529/http://thepeoplescharter.org/ Archive of the official website]

revision.text:
The '''theory of criminal justice''' is the branch of [[philosophy of law]] that deals with [[criminal justice]] and in particular [[punishment]]. The theory of criminal justice has deep connections to other areas of philosophy, such as [[political philosophy]] and [[ethics]], as well as to criminal justice in practice.
==Justice and criminal justice==
===Distinction from general justice=== Typically, legal theorists and philosophers consider four distinct kinds of justice: corrective justice, distributive justice, procedural justice, and retributive justice.<ref>Richard A. Posner, The Problems of Jurisprudence. pp. 313-352</ref> Corrective justice is the idea that liability rectifies the injustice one person inflicts upon another (found in modern day contract law).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weinrib|first=Ernest J.|date=2002|title=Corrective Justice in a Nutshell|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/825933|journal=The University of Toronto Law Journal|volume=52|issue=4|pages=349|doi=10.2307/825933|issn=0042-0220}}</ref> Distributive justice seeks to appropriately distribute pleasure and pain between the offender and the victim by punishing the offender.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/863695610|title=Economic analysis of law|last=author.|first=Posner, Richard A.,|isbn=9781454833888|oclc=863695610}}</ref> [[Procedural justice]] focuses on the fairness in the processes that punish criminals. Retributive justice is perhaps best captured by the phrase ''lex talionis'' (the principle of "an [[eye for an eye]]"), which traces back to the book of Exodus.<ref>Exodus 21:23–27.</ref>
Criminal law generally falls under retributive justice, a theory of justice that considers proportionate punishment a morally acceptable response to crime. The principle of ''lex talionis'' received its most well known philosophical defense from Immanuel Kant.<ref>Kant, Immanuel. (original 1785.) Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals. Grundlegung zur Metaphysik der Sitten. (in German)</ref> Criminal law is no longer considered a purely retributive undertaking; deterrence figures prominently in the justification of the practice and in the rules themselves.<ref>See e.g., H.L.A. Hart, Liberty and Morality (1963)</ref>
==See also== * [[Marginal deterrence]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Legal ethics]] [[Category:Social philosophy]] [[Category:Criminal justice]]

page.title: Threatening government officials of the United States

revision.text:
{{Criminal law}} '''Threatening government officials of the United States''' is a [[felony]] under [[Law of the United States|federal law]]. [[Threatening the President of the United States]] is a felony under {{usc|18|871}}, punishable by up to 5 years of imprisonment, that is investigated by the [[United States Secret Service]]. Threatening other officials is a Class C or D felony, usually carrying maximum penalties of 5 or 10 years under {{usc|18|875}}, {{usc|18|876}} and other statutes, that is investigated by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]. When national boundaries are transcended by such a threat, it is considered a [[terrorist threat]].<ref>{{uscsub|18|2332b|a|2}}</ref>
When a threat is made against a judge, it can be considered [[obstruction of justice]].<ref>{{usc|18|1503}}</ref> Threatening federal officials' family members is also a federal crime; in enacting the law, the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|Committee on the Judiciary]] stated that "Clearly it is a proper Federal function to respond to terrorists and other criminals who seek to influence the making of Federal policies and interfere with the administration of justice by attacking close relatives of those entrusted with these tasks."<ref name="From Archive.org-8554828">{{cite web |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/809/809.F2d.579.86-3085.html |title=UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee,v.James Edward GRAY, Defendant-Appellant.; No. 86-3085.; United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit. |work=bulk.resource.org |date=February 3, 1987 |accessdate=April 6, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504155555/http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/809/809.F2d.579.86-3085.html |archivedate=May 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->}}</ref>
There are three elements of the offense of making an illegal threat: (i) there must be a transmission in interstate commerce; (ii) there must be a communication containing the threat; (iii) and the threat must be a threat to injure the person of another.<ref>{{cite court|litigants=United States v. DeAndino|vol=958|reporter=F.2d|opinion=146|court=US Ct. App. 6th Cir.|date=1992}}</ref> Threats can also sometimes be punished under the statutes criminalizing [[assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain United States Government officers or employees]]<ref>{{cite court|litigants=United States v. Heliczer|vol=373|reporter=F. 2d|opinion=241|court=Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit|date=1967}}</ref> or [[Assaulting, kidnapping, and assassinating the government officials of the United States|assassinating, kidnapping, and assaulting government officials of the United States]].
[[United States Sentencing Guidelines]] take a number of factors into consideration in determining the recommended penalty, including evidence of the person's intent to carry out the threat; disruption to the government function; and the possibility of inciting others to violence.<ref>{{citation|title=U.S.S.G. §2A6.1|url=http://www.ussc.gov/2009guid/2a6_1.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618204634/http://www.ussc.gov/2009guid/2a6_1.htm|archivedate=2010-06-18|df=}}</ref> There is also a 6-level [[official victim]] enhancement, which makes the recommended penalty, per the [[sentencing table]], approximately double that which would apply if an ordinary citizen were the victim.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.ussc.gov/2009guid/3a1_2.htm|title=U.S.S.G. §3A1.2|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618140656/http://www.ussc.gov/2009guid/3a1_2.htm|archivedate=2010-06-18|df=}}</ref> There can be many motives for making threats, including political motives or a desire to frame someone else for making the threat.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_14495305|title=Community College of Aurora librarian charged in mail threats|author1=Howard Pankratz |author2=Joey Bunch |lastauthoramp=yes |work=The Denver Post|date=March 2, 2010}}</ref> The person's intent can greatly affect the sentence.
In determining what constitutes a [[true threat]], the courts hold that what must be proved is that a reasonable recipient of the communication would consider it a threat under the circumstances. Thus, a statement to a judge that "You and your family are going to die" would be regarded as a true threat, even if the defendant claimed that he meant it as a literal, biological truth.<ref>{{cite court|volume=443|reporter=F3d|court=10th Cir.|opinion=1310|date=2006|litigants=United States v. Teague|url=http://openjurist.org/443/f3d/1310/united-states-v-teague}}</ref> If a threat is made to multiple individuals, it may be considered to be outside of the guidelines heartland, and therefore to warrant an enhancement.<ref>{{cite court|volume=168|reporter=F.3d|opinion=84|url=http://cases.justia.com/us-court-of-appeals/F3/168/84/569079/|litigants=United States of America, Appellee, v. Samuel Adelman, Defendant-appellant|date=Feb 19, 1999}}</ref>
==Incidents==
===President=== {{main|Threatening the President of the United States}} The Secret Service prefers not to publicize incidents of Presidential assassination threats, because it believes that it will generate more criminal behavior, especially among the mentally ill.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/eousa/foia_reading_room/usam/title9/65mcrm.htm#9-65.140|title=U.S. Attorneys' Manual|chapter=9-65.140 Publicity Concerning Threats Against Government Officials}}</ref> Reports have circulated in the British press that [[Barack Obama]] received four times as many threats as his predecessor,<ref>{{citation|title=Barack Obama faces 30 death threats a day, stretching US Secret Service|date=3 Aug 2009|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/5967942/Barack-Obama-faces-30-death-threats-a-day-stretching-US-Secret-Service.html | location=London | first=Toby | last=Harnden}}</ref> a claim that Secret Service Director [[Mark J. Sullivan|Mark Sullivan]] denies.<ref>{{citation|url=http://tpmlivewire.talkingpointsmemo.com/2009/12/secret-service-director-threats-against-obama-not-up.php|title=Secret Service Director: Threats Against Obama Not Up|date=December 3, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091207114540/http://tpmlivewire.talkingpointsmemo.com/2009/12/secret-service-director-threats-against-obama-not-up.php|archivedate=December 7, 2009|df=}}</ref> Historically, prosecutions for Presidential assassination threats have risen during periods of national crisis, such as the [[World Wars]] and the [[Vietnam War]] era.<ref name=Comment>Comment, Threatening the President: Protected Dissenter or Potential Assassin, 57 Geo. L.J. 553 (1969)</ref> New communication technologies such as [[Facebook]],<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2009/09/29/secret-service-probing-obama-assassination-poll-facebook/|title=Secret Service Probing Obama Assassination Poll on Facebook|date=September 29, 2009|publisher=Fox News}}</ref><ref>{{citation|work=Washington Examiner|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/blogs/Examiner-Opinion-Zone/Should-Facebook-remove-groups-that-want-to-kill-George-W-Bush-62568487.html|title=Should Facebook remove groups that want to kill George W. Bush?|date=Sep 29, 2009|author=Charlie Spiering}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> [[MySpace]],<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,220779,00.html|title=Teen Questioned Over Online Threats Against President Bush|date=October 14, 2006|publisher=Fox News}}</ref> and [[Twitter]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/health-care-bill-spurs-assassination-calls-twitter/story?id=10170233&page=1|title=Health Care Bill Spurs Assassination Calls on Twitter|author1=Goldman, Russell |author2=Ryan, Jason |lastauthoramp=yes |date=March 22, 2010|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> have become vectors for investigated alleged threats against the President. After the 2016 Presidential election [[mashable.com]] reported 12,000 calls for President Donald Trump's assassination in [[Twitter]]. <ref name="mashable_lekach">{{Cite web |url=https://mashable.com/2017/02/02/threatening-posts-secret-service/#pNqj86LQU5qB |title=Over 12,000 tweets are calling for Trump's assassination. Here's how the Secret Service handles it |last=Lekach |first=Sasha |website=Mashable |language=en |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
===Legislators=== There have been comparatively few physical assaults on [[Members of Congress]]. On May 22, 1856, Senator [[Charles Sumner]] was savagely beaten down to the floor of the Senate chamber with a gold-knobbed cane by Representative [[Preston Brooks]] after Sumner delivered a fiery oration against [[slavery]]. <ref name="US Senate Brooks">{{Cite web |url=https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/minute/The_Caning_of_Senator_Charles_Sumner.htm |title=U.S. Senate: The Caning of Senator Charles Sumner |website=www.senate.gov |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> A century later, four [[Puerto Rican nationalist]]s opened fire on the House chamber, wounding five Members of Congress.<ref name=Cleveland/> Representative [[Gabrielle Giffords]] was shot and severely injured on January 2011 outside a supermarket where she met with constituents. <ref name="NYT_giffords">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/09/us/politics/09giffords.html |title=Representative Gabrielle Giffords and 18 Shot Near Tucson |last=Herszenhorn |first=Marc Lacey and David M. |language=en |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> Representative [[Steve Scalise]] was gravely wounded in 2017 when he was shot by a former volunteer for [[Bernie Sanders]]'s 2016 Presidential campaign. <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/14/us/steve-scalise-congress-shot-alexandria-virginia.html |title=Congressman Steve Scalise Gravely Wounded in Alexandria Baseball Field Ambush |language=en |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref> Senator [[Rand Paul]] suffered several rib fractures and developed pneumonia after a November 2017 attack by a neighbor over a dispute over lawn care. <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/15/us/politics/rand-paul-attack.html |title=Rand Paul’s Neighbor Is Sentenced to 30 Days in Prison After Attack |language=en |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
Threats and intimidation directed against Members of Congress are more common than physical assaults. A prominent example was [[cross burning|the burning of a cross, an intimidation tactic of]] the [[Ku Klux Klan]], on [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|House Speaker]] [[Sam Rayburn]]'s front lawn in Texas during debate on [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|civil rights legislation]] in the 1960s.<ref name=Cleveland>{{citation|url=http://www.cleveland.com/nation/index.ssf/2010/03/congress_members_reveal_more_d.html|title=Congress members reveal more details about threats|date=March 26, 2010|agency=Associated Press|author1=Kellman, Laurie |author2=Abrams, Jim |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref> The [[United States Capital Police]] investigates threats against Members of Congress and reports to the Chair and Ranking Member of the [[Committee on House Administration]] and/or the [[United States Senate Committee on Rules and Administration]].
Social media have been used to publish threats and intimidating messages. Threats have been made through [[YouTube]] videos <ref>{{citation|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0410/35501.html|title=Man arrested for Nancy Pelosi threats|work=Politico|author=Sherman, Jake|date=April 7, 2010}}</ref> and [[Twitter]] (which hosted direct threats of violence against Members of Congress such as Representative [[Bob Goodlatte]], and Senators [[Roy Blunt]] and [[John Hoeven]]). Concern has been voiced in the press over Twitter's failure in some cases to promptly remove threats made against Members of Congress. Kyler Schmitz's threats to shoot Senator Roy Blunt remained on Twitter after Schmitz had been arrested for illegally using interstate communications to make the threat. <ref name="TheHill_Twitter">{{Cite web |url=https://thehill.com/policy/technology/285161-twitter-fails-to-take-down-death-threats-to-gop-senators |title=Death threats against senators remained on Twitter for 2 weeks |last=Swanson |first=Ian |date=2016-06-28 |website=TheHill |language=en |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> Christopher Michael McGowan was arrested in April 2018 for a series of [[Twitter#Tweets|Tweets]] threatening Representative Goodlatte and other lawmakers made from January to April 2018. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/virginia-man-arrested-threatening-congressman-article-1.3919799 |title=Virginia man arrested for making repeated threats against Republican congressman - NY Daily News |last=Chia |first=Jessica |website=nydailynews.com |language=en-US |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> Twitter's stated policy on "Violent threats and glorification of violence" says "You may not make specific threats of violence or wish for the serious physical harm, death, or disease of an individual or group of people". <ref name="twitterpolicy">{{Cite web |url=https://help.twitter.com/en/rules-and-policies/violent-threats-glorification |title=Violent threats and glorification of violence |language=en |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
2010 legislation for [[health care reform in the United States]] saw an increased number of threatening communications and actions directed at legislators. Several Members of Congress received threatening messages. Representative [[Eric Cantor]] received a threat from Norman Leboon, a donor to Barack Obama who had produced more than 2,000 threatening YouTube videos;<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/POLITICS/03/29/cantor.threat.arrest/index.html?hpt=T2 | work=CNN | title=Man accused of making threats against Cantor | date=March 29, 2010}}</ref> the Democratic Party said that it would donate the funds to charity.<ref>{{cite web|last=O'Brien |first=Michael |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/89667-dnc-will-give-cantor-threat-suspects-donations-to-charity |title=DNC will give Cantor threat suspect's donations to charity - The Hill's Blog Briefing Room |publisher=Thehill.com |date=2010-03-29 |accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref> Other lawmakers' windows were broken with bricks and other objects.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/03/24/fbi-investigates-possible-threats-directed-house-democrats/|title=FBI Probes Threats Directed at House Democrats|publisher=Fox News|date=March 24, 2010}}</ref>
[[House Minority Leader]] [[John Boehner]] stated, "Violence and threats are unacceptable. Yes, I know there is anger, but let's take that anger, and go out and register people to vote, go volunteer on a political campaign, and let's do it the right way."<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB20001424052748704094104575143782325623718|title=Parties Exchange Barbs Over Threat Reports|date=March 26, 2010|author1=Bendavid, Naftali |author2=Johnson, Fawn |lastauthoramp=yes |work=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Rep. Cantor, who received a bullet through his campaign office window, stated, "Security threats against members of Congress are not a partisan issue, and they should never be treated that way. To use such threats as political weapons is reprehensible."<ref name="USAToday_Cantor">{{citation|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2010-03-25-threats_N.htm|title=House leaders decry threats, dish out blame|author=Kelley, Matt|work=USA Today|date=2010-03-25}}</ref> He accused Representative [[Chris Van Hollen]] of "dangerously fanning the flames by suggesting that these incidents be used as a political weapon."<ref>{{citation|url=http://congress.blogs.foxnews.com/2010/03/27/words-have-power/|title=Words Have Power|author=Pergram, Chad|date=2010-03-27|publisher=Fox News}}</ref> A spokesman for the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] remarked, "I think it is astounding that we are seeing this wave of [[vigilantism]]."<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ieYu07gp70-7oDIgoUOqgoWq4GtQD9ELGOOG3|title=Dems deal with threats over health care support|author=Pettus, Emily Wagster|agency=Associated Press|date=2010-03-25}}</ref>
After the 2016 Presidential election, personal attacks gained a more prominent place in dialogue between the President and legislators from both major US parties, with at least one Member of Congress advocating harassment of other Federal officials outside of work. In June 2018, Representative [[Maxine Waters]], speaking at an outdoor rally said, "If you see anybody from that (Trump) Cabinet in a restaurant, in a department store, at a gasoline station, you get out and you create a crowd and you push back on them, and you tell them they're not welcome anymore, anywhere." <ref name="NPR_waters">{{Cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/06/25/623206039/congressional-leaders-criticize-maxine-waters-for-urging-confrontation |title=Congressional Leaders Criticize Maxine Waters For Urging Confrontation |website=NPR.org |language=en |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
In July 2018, Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] was confronted with shouted personal insults and the threat "we know where you live" by a crowd of protesters; earlier, McConnell and his wife [[Elaine Chao]] were subjected to verbal abuse by a crowd as they left an event at Georgetown University. <ref name="CNN_McConnell">{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/08/politics/mitch-mcconnell-louisville-protest/index.html |title=McConnell chased from KY restaurant by protesters |last=CNN |first=Devan Cole, |website=CNN |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref> According to National Public Radio, at least three Trump administration officials — [[Secretary of Homeland Security]] [[Kirstjen Nielsen]], Trump adviser [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]] and White House Press Secretary [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]], along with her family — have been forced out by vocal protesters from restaurants or denied service. <ref name="NPR_waters" />
While Senate Minority Leader [[Charles Schumer]] and House Minority Leader [[Nancy Pelosi]] denounced the tactic of harassing their political enemies. Both Schumer and Pelosi referred to President Trump's personal attacks on political opponents on [[Twitter]] while disavowing the tactics of Rep. Maxine Waters. <ref name="NPR_waters" />
During Senate confirmation hearings on [[Brett Kavanaugh]]'s appointment to the US Supreme Court, Senator [[Ted Cruz]]'s Houston campaign office received an envelope containing white powder just after two envelopes containing the poison [[ricin]] were mailed to US [[Secretary of Defense]] [[James Mattis]] and the [[Chief of Naval Operations]]. <ref name="cruz_whitepowder">{{Cite web |url=https://nypost.com/2018/10/02/white-powder-mailed-to-ted-cruzs-office/ |title=White powder mailed to Ted Cruz’s office |date=2018-10-02 |website=New York Post |language=en-US |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref> Sen. Cruz and his wife also had to leave their table at a Washington restaurant when protesters shouted them down at their table. <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/25/politics/ted-cruz-heckled-restaurant-brett-kavanaugh/index.html |title=Ted Cruz forced from restaurant amid Kavanaugh drama |last=CNN |first=Devan Cole, |website=CNN |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
According to ''[[Newsweek]]'', Senator Susan Collins's office received "threatening, profanity-laced phone calls and letters, telling her to vote against the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court". One caller told a young woman working for Collins that he hoped she would be raped and impregnated, according to a voicemail provided to the ''[[New York Times]]'' by Collins's spokeswoman. <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.newsweek.com/brett-kavanaugh-susan-collins-threats-1118121 |title=Staffers of Maine GOP Senator Susan Collins are receiving threatening and vulgar calls over Brett Kavanaugh. |date=2018-09-12 |website=Newsweek |language=en |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
[[Doxing]] of legislators also occurs. Jackson A. Cosko, a member of Representative [[Sheila Jackson Lee]]'s staff, was arrested by US Capitol Police in October 2018, charged with public restricted information, unauthorized access of a government computer, burglary, threatening Federal officials and other crimes. <ref name="Chronicle Cosko">{{Cite web |url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/politics/article/Sheila-Jackson-Lee-intern-arrested-for-doxing-13279983.php |title=Sheila Jackson Lee intern accused of 'doxing' GOP senators in Kavanaugh battle |date=2018-10-04 |website=HoustonChronicle.com |language=en-US |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> According to a Federal arrest warrant filed by Capitol Police, Cosko threatened an aide of Senator [[Maggie Hassan]] who found him using a computer in Sen. Hassan's office, then ordered him to leave in an E-mail: "“If you tell anyone I will leak it all. Emails signal conversations gmails. Senators children’s health information and socials...” Mr. Cosko posted confidential personal information such as home and office addresses and home telephone numbers of five US senators, including Senate Judiciary Committee members [[Lindsey Graham]], [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]] and [[Orrin Hatch]], to their [[Wikipedia]] articles. <ref name="WaPo_Cosko">{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/democratic-ex-staffer-contests-charges-he-posted-personal-data-on-gop-senators-threatened-witness-in-doxing/2018/10/04/88842844-c806-11e8-b2b5-79270f9cce17_story.html |title=Democratic ex-staffer contests charges he posted personal data on GOP senators, threatened witness in doxing |website=Washington Post |language=en |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
[[Cyberstalking]] of legislators is a related problem. Juan McCullum, a former member of Congressional delegate [[Stacey Plaskett]] and Representative [[Frederica Wilson]] was charged in July 2017 with illegally obtaining private nude photographs of Delegate Plaskett and videos of her family from Ms. Plaskett's [[iPhone]] while he worked for her, then using an Internet account under an assumed name to distribute the photos and encourage other Internet users to share them online. <ref name="WaPo_McCullum">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/two-former-staffers-charged-in-cyberstalking-of-us-house-member-husband/2017/07/13/535e2038-680e-11e7-a1d7-9a32c91c6f40_story.html |title=Two former staffers charged in cyberstalking of U.S. House member, husband |access-date=2018-10-08 |language=en}}</ref>
===Judges and prosecutors=== Threats against federal judges can include threats of [[vigilantism]]. For instance, in 2004, gun-rights activist, Denver businessman and former Libertarian candidate for U.S. Senate Rick Stanley was sentenced to six years of imprisonment for sending two judges, Thornton Municipal Judge Charles J. Rose and 17th Judicial District Judge Donald W. Marshall, Jr., a "notice of order" demanding that they reverse his conviction for a weapons violation or face arrest by Stanley's Mutual Defense Pact Militia and a trial for [[treason]]. Stanley was also ordered to pay $8,250 restitution to police who worked overtime to protect the judges.<ref>{{citation|author=Julie Poppen|work=Rocky Mountain News|date=September 11, 2004|title=Six-year prison term for gun-rights activist: Threats to judges called 'an assault' on justice system}}</ref>
Threats against federal judges and prosecutors have more than doubled in recent years, with threats against federal prosecutors rising from 116 to 250 from 2003 to 2008,<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.mainjustice.com/2010/01/04/threats-against-federal-prosecutors-increased-during-2000s/|title=Threats Against Federal Prosecutors Increased During 2000s|author=Andrew Ramonas|date=January 4, 2010|publisher=Main Justice|access-date=2010-03-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717003404/http://www.mainjustice.com/2010/01/04/threats-against-federal-prosecutors-increased-during-2000s/#|archive-date=2011-07-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and threats against federal judges climbing from 500 to 1,278 in that same period,<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/05/29/Threats-against-federal-judges-increase/UPI-65931243638685/|title=Threats against federal judges increase|date=May 29, 2009|publisher=UPI}}</ref> <ref>{{citation|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2010-01-04-judge-threats-increase_N.htm|title=Threats against federal judges, prosecutors are up|date=January 4, 2010|work=USA Today}}</ref> prompting hundreds to get 24-hour protection from armed [[U.S. marshal]]s. The problem has become so pronounced that a threat management center has been opened in [[Crystal City, Arlington, Virginia]], where a staff of about 25 marshals and analysts monitor a 24-hour number for reporting threats, use sophisticated [[Geographic information system|mapping software]] to track those being threatened and tap into a classified database linked to the FBI and [[CIA]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/24/AR2009052402931.html|title=Threats to Judges, Prosecutors Soaring|date=May 25, 2009|work=The Washington Post|author=Markon, Jerry}}</ref> In 2009, a [[radio host]] was indicted for, after criticizing three [[appellate judge]]s of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]] who affirmed a lower court decision to dismiss challenges to Chicago's [[handgun ban]] as "cunning, ruthless, untrustworthy, disloyal, unpatriotic, deceitful scum", allegedly saying, "Let me be the first to say this plainly: These judges deserve to be killed."<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009/07/radio-host-denies-threatening-federal-judges.html|title=Radio host denies threatening federal judges|date=July 28, 2009|work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref> He also allegedly posted blog entries providing a photo and a map of the [[Dirksen Federal Building]] in Chicago, where the court is located, with arrows pointing to "anti-[[truck bomb]] barriers."<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202435781035|title=Trial Over Death Threats Against Federal Judges Could Test Free Speech Rules Online|work=National Law Journal|date=November 24, 2009|author=Lynne Marek}}</ref> That case resulted in two [[hung juries]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mistrial-number-2-for-blogger-accused-of-threatening-federal-judges-2010-3|title=Mistrial Number 2 For Blogger Accused Of Threatening Federal Judges|author=Erin Geiger Smith|date=Mar 11, 2010|work=Business Insider Law Review}}</ref> The sending of white powder as part of a threatening communication has become common since the [[2001 anthrax attacks]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.ktiv.com/Global/story.asp?S=12185086|title=Man sentenced for threatening Neb. federal judge|date=March 22, 2010|agency=Associated Press}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The making of these threats coincided with high-profile violence against federal officials in that same period, including Baltimore Assistant U.S. Attorney [[Jonathan Luna]], who was stabbed 36 times with his own penknife and drowned in a creek, and [[Thomas C. Wales]], an assistant U.S. attorney in Seattle gunned down at his home. Such incidents lead U.S. officials to take threats seriously. However, actual attacks on government officials are still rare in the U.S. relative to many countries with more unstable governments (e.g. so-called "[[banana republic]]s" that frequently experience [[coup]]s and assassinations) as evidenced by the fact that the most famous judge to be assassinated in recent times was [[John H. Wood, Jr.]] back in 1979.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/localnews/20031214fedthreats1214p3.asp|title=Threats part of landscape for prosecutors|date=December 14, 2003|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|author=Torsten Ove}}</ref>
Case law records that many threats are made from prisoners dissatisfied with the handling of their own case or fellow inmates', or wanting to serve time in the federal system.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/nebraska/article_077b07b0-3609-11df-84af-001cc4c03286.html|title= Missouri man to prison for threatening judge|date=March 22, 2010|work=Lincoln Journal Star}}</ref> Often the penalties for making the threat are more serious than those imposed for the original offense.<ref>{{citation|title=Man Sentenced for Threatening Federal Officials in Arizona|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/cas/press/cas90616-Salazar.pdf|date=June 16, 2009|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice|access-date=2010-03-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528073724/http://www.justice.gov/usao/cas/press/cas90616-Salazar.pdf#|archive-date=2010-05-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Threats by inmates are taken seriously if the person has contacts on the outside who are capable of carrying out the threat. Federal officials attribute the rising threat rate to disgruntled defendants, terrorism and gang cases that bring more violent offenders into federal courts, frustration over the [[Great Recession|economic crisis]] and the rise of the "[[sovereign citizen]]" movement – a loose collection of [[tax protester]]s, [[white supremacist]]s and others who don't respect federal authority.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/09/AR2009060903669.html|title=Guarding the Halls of Justice Against an Escalating Threat|author=Jerry Markon|date=June 11, 2009|work=Washington Post}}</ref>
Social media has become notable in threats against high-profile Federal judges. Several threats or encouragements of others to kill [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]] judge [[Brett Kavanaugh]] or members of the Senate who supported confirmation of his appointment to the [[US Supreme Court]] were made on [[Twitter]]. Twitter formally forbids users to "make specific threats of violence or wish for the serious physical harm, death, or disease of an individual or group of people". <ref name="twitterpolicy" /> <ref name="Rosemount_threat">{{Cite web |url=https://bringmethenews.com/minnesota-news/rosemount-teacher-suspended-for-tweet-threatening-brett-kavanaugh |title=Rosemount teacher suspended for Brett Kavanaugh threat tweet |website=Bring Me The News |language=en |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> <ref name="MHerald_Fair">{{Cite web |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article219376490.html |title=Kavanaugh supporters should be castrated, D.C. professor wrote. Twitter shut her down |website=miamiherald |language=en |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
===Other civil servants=== The [[Internal Revenue Service]] is frequently a target of threats. Examples include the case of ''U.S. v. Darby'', in which the defendant told the IRS he was tired of their [[bullshit]], asked how they would like to have a [[pipe bomb]] delivered to their place of employment, and said that he didn't eat his victims like [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] but just killed them by blowing them up;<ref>{{cite court|litigants=United States v. Darby|court=4th Cir.|date= October 21, 1994|vol=37|reporter=F.3d|opinion=1059}}</ref> David J. D'Addabbo, who sent a petition to IRS workers warning that they would be "tried by a jury and your penalty will be sought for it to be death by [[firing squad]]" and told the arresting agents to "watch your back";<ref>{{citation|title=Man admits threatening IRS|work=Deseret News | location=Salt Lake City|author=Geoffrey Fattah|date=August 15, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Cache County man charged with threatening IRS workers|work=Deseret News |location=Salt Lake City|date=March 21, 2006|author=Winslow, Ben}}</ref> and John Barker, who perpetrated an [[anthrax hoax]] against the IRS. According to the [[U.S. Treasury Department]]'s Inspector General for Tax Administration, threats against the IRS have been rising in recent years, and in 2009 rose from 834 to 1,014 per year,<ref>{{citation|title=Threats Against IRS Employees on the Rise, Official Says|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704757904575077381781219798|author=Vaughan, Martin|date=February 21, 2010|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> an increase of 21.5% over the prior year.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/01/threats-against-irs-emplo_n_481455.html|title=Threats Against IRS Employees On The Rise, Increased 21 Percent From 2008 To 2009|date=March 1, 2010|work=Huffington Post|author=Marcus Baram}}</ref> There have been incidents of actual violence against the IRS to take place as well, by people ramming cars into IRS offices, setting them on fire, and taking out hits on IRS employees,<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2010/03/13/threats_against_irs_workers_continue/|title=Threats against IRS workers continue|date=March 13, 2010|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> although the [[2010 Austin plane crash]] was one of the more high-profile incidents. According to a [[Cato Institute]] commentator, "this trend is likely to continue until there is a fundamental change in our tax laws and collection methods. People who do not have access to the media and cannot afford expensive tax lawyers sometimes reach such a level of frustration with the IRS that they resort to violent or irrational behavior."<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.cato.org/pub_display.php?pub_id=11659|title=Morality and the IRS|author=Rahn, Richard W.|date=April 6, 2010|publisher=The Cato Institute}}</ref> There is a special statute, {{usc|26|7212}}, that protects IRS employees from threats, which according to the [[U.S. Attorneys' Manual]], "provides a particularly helpful alternative in cases where there is simply an offer of violence unaccompanied by the potential for imminent use of physical force."<ref>http://www.justice.gov/usao/eousa/foia_reading_room/usam/title9/crm01572.htm</ref>
Federal law enforcement agencies are often the target of threats. Examples include Jeff Henry Williamson, who threatened to blow up FBI headquarters, CIA headquarters and the Justice Department;<ref>{{citation|url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news/local&id=7324194|title=Houston jury convicts man of threatening FBI, CIA|date=March 10, 2010|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> and Micha Godfrey, who allegedly emailed [[medical cannabis]] websites threats against DEA agents and their families, and a search of whose house subsequently turned up four firearms, a [[bulletproof vest]], and cannabis plants.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.ticklethewire.com/2010/03/15/calif-man-under-investigation-for-threatening-lives-of-dea-agents-and-families-arrested/|title= Calif. Man Under Investigation for Threatening Lives of DEA Agents and Families Arrested|author=Allan Lengel|date=2010-03-15|publisher=TickleTheWire.com}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2010/03/13/1810642/calif-man-investigated-over-alleged.html|title=Calif. man investigated over alleged DEA threats|agency=Associated Press|date=March 3, 2013|publisher=KansasCity.com}}</ref> Government agencies are sometimes the subject of [[blackmail]] attempts, as when an informer threatened to falsely accuse the FBI of knowing in advance that the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] would be [[September 11 attacks|bombed]] and of failing to stop it.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/07/nyregion/informer-in-terrorism-trial-admits-threatening-fbi.html?pagewanted=1|title=Informer in Terrorism Trial Admits Threatening F.B.I.|date=April 7, 1995|author=Fried, Joseph P. | work=The New York Times}}</ref>
[[Doxing]] is also used against law enforcement officers. During the controversy over full enforcement of immigration laws in the United States in June 2018, the activist Web site [[wikileaks]] published the identities of over 9,000 alleged current and former employees of [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] gleaned from the [[LinkedIn]] Web site, with their places of employment and contact information. <ref name="wikileaks_ICE">{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/06/22/wikileaks-publishes-identities-and-information-about-ice-employees-amid-intensifying-anger/ |title=WikiLeaks publishes identities and information about ICE employees amid intensifying anger |website=Washington Post |language=en |access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
==Enforcement== When the FBI receives threats over the Internet, it can use [[National Security Letter]]s to obtain the real name, street address and Internet logs of the sender, and those who provide the information were forbidden by the [[PATRIOT Act]] from revealing the request to anyone, until the ''[[Doe v. Ashcroft]]'' case overturned that [[gag rule]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-07-05-fbi-letters_x.htm|title=With only a letter, FBI can gather private data|date=July 6, 2006|author=Richard Willing|work=USA Today}}</ref> According to the federal investigators, political protesters who threaten elected officials or turn violent are easier for law enforcement officials to track due to their vocal and high-profile statements on the internet. For instance, Nigel Coleman posted the address of Rep. [[Tom Perriello]] online and invited people to "visit" the official at his home. The address was actually Perriello's brother Bo. A severed gas line at the home was discovered one day after the address was made public.<ref>{{citation|title=Tea Party makes tracking political criminals easier for law enforcement|date=March 26, 2010|author=McCabe, Virginia|work=FBI Examiner}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2010/03/24/2240928.aspx|title=FBI Looks into Gas Line Cut|date=March 24, 2010|author=Domenico Montanaro|publisher=MSNBC}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2008}} The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF) is an international non-profit advocacy and legal organization based in the United States.
==1990–1995== *July 10, 1990: EFF is founded and the groundwork is laid for the successful representation of [[Steve Jackson Games]] in a Federal court case to prosecute the [[United States Secret Service]] for unlawfully raiding their offices and seizing computers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tuxradar.com/content/inside-electronic-frontier-foundation|title=Inside the Electronic Frontier Foundation {{!}} TuxRadar Linux|website=www.tuxradar.com|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2015/05/08/your-cyberpunk-games-are-dange.html|title=Your cyberpunk games are dangerous|last=Peterson|first=Jon|date=2015-05-08|website=Boing Boing|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> *1991: [[Steve Jackson Games]] v. United States Secret Service. EFF files in federal court.<ref>{{Citation|title=Steve Jackson Games, Inc. v. US Secret Service|date=March 12, 1993|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/816/432/1976489/|accessdate=2017-09-22}}</ref> *1992: EFF gives first annual [[EFF Pioneer Award|Pioneer Awards]] at 2nd [[Computers, Freedom and Privacy Conference]] in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://w2.eff.org/awards/pioneer/1992.php|title=EFF: 1992 Pioneer Awards: Engelbart, Kahn, Warren, Jennings and Smereczynski Honored with EFF Pioneer Awards at Special Washington Ceremony|website=w2.eff.org|language=en|access-date=2017-01-23}}</ref> *March 12th, 1993: ''[[Steve Jackson Games, Inc. v. United States Secret Service]]''. [[Steve Jackson Games]] wins its case against the [[United States Secret Service]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Steve Jackson Games, Inc. v. US Secret Service|date=March 12, 1993|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=15578406156657124091&q=steve+harvey+games&hl=en&as_sdt=6,33|volume=816|pages=432|accessdate=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.osnews.com/story/24807/IO_com_To_Disappear_Piece_of_Internet_History_Lost|title=IO.com To Disappear, Piece of Internet History Lost|last=Staff|first=OSNews|website=www.osnews.com|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> *1994: [[Center for Democracy and Technology]] is formed by Jerry Berman. *1994: [[Scientology and the Internet|Scientology v. the Internet]]. *1995: ''[[Bernstein v. United States]]''. [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] rules in favor of [[Daniel J. Bernstein]], holding that [[computer software|software]] [[source code]] is speech protected by the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] and that the government's regulations preventing its publication were [[Constitutionality|unconstitutional]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://epic.org/crypto/export_controls/bernstein_decision_9_cir.html|title=Bernstein v. USDOJ (9th Cir. May 6, 1999)|website=epic.org|access-date=2017-01-23}}</ref> *1995: EFF moves to San Francisco.
==1995–1999== *1995–1996: EFF opens its "Blue Ribbon Campaign" in direct response to the [[Communications Decency Act]]. *1996: EFF mounts its "Golden Key Campaign" to back calls for liberalisation of [[Export_of_cryptography|cryptography export laws]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://w2.eff.org/Privacy/Crypto_export/Crypto_bills_1996/eff_procode_ipc_goldkey_960502.announce |title=EFF Helps Plant Seeds of 'Golden Key' Grassroots Campaign For Secure Electronic Communications | Electronic Frontier Foundation |publisher=Eff.org |date=May 2, 1996 |accessdate=2009-11-30}}</ref> *1996: EFF co-founds [[TRUSTe]], the first Privacy Seal company, with CommerceNet, a non-profit industry consortium. *1998: EFF builds [[EFF DES cracker|Deep Crack]], a machine that decrypts a [[Data Encryption Standard|DES]]-encrypted message after only 56 hours of work, winning [[RSA Security]]'s DES Challenge II-2. *1999: EFF and Anonymizer launch the Kosovo Privacy Project, an anonymous and secure email and Web surfing service conceived by Alex Fowler and Patrick Ball to ensure the protection of Kosovars, Serbs, and others reporting on the [[Kosovo War]] within the region from reprisal from Serbian officials.
==2001–2004== *2001: ''[[Felten v. RIAA]]''. EFF supports [[Edward Felten]] in suing RIAA after [[Secure Digital Music Initiative]] (SDMI), RIAA, and [[Verance Corporation]] threaten Felten with legal action under the terms of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) over Felten's plan to present a paper about methods for defeating the SDMI watermarks. The case is dismissed. *April 2002: EFF supports the [[Chilling Effects (group)|Chilling Effects Clearinghouse]] effort to organize a database of IP law abuse and educate potential victims. * November 2002: ''[[Universal v. Reimerdes]]'' ("''[[2600: The Hacker Quarterly|2600]]'' magazine case"). EFF loses its appeal before the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit Court of Appeals]], establishing a legal precedent to permit [[prior restraint]]. ''2600'' magazine is restrained from publishing links to the Second Circuit code under provisions of the DMCA and declines to appeal to the Supreme Court. *December 2003: ''[[RIAA v. Verizon]]'', D.C. Cir. EFF supports [[Verizon Communications]] in a successful challenge to a lower court ruling holding that the company must reveal the identity of a Verizon customer accused of copyright infringement using the [[peer-to-peer]] file-sharing software [[Kazaa]]. The DC Circuit Court of Appeals agrees with Verizon and EFF that the special subpoena provisions in the DMCA apply to potentially infringing material stored on an [[Internet service provider|ISP]] server, not material stored on an individual's own computer. *2004: ''[[DirecTV v. Treworgy]]'', 11th Circuit. EFF helps defend "smart card" technology owner Mike Treworgy after [[DirecTV]] sued him based on the fact that he purchased hardware that could be used to intercept the company's satellite TV signals. Treworgy prevails in the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals, which finds that DirecTV cannot sue individuals for "mere possession" of smart-card technology. In separate negotiations with DirecTV, EFF succeeds in getting the company to drop its "guilt-by-purchase" litigation strategy altogether. *2004-02-18: EFF files [[amicus curiae]] brief in ''1-800 Contacts, Inc. v. WhenU.Com and Vision Direct, Inc.'' appeal (see [[1-800 Contacts]]) *April 19, 2004: EFF initiates the [[Patent Busting Project]] to challenge "illegitimate patents that suppress non-commercial and small business innovation or limit free expression online" *May 2004: [[American Civil Liberties Union v. Ashcroft (2004)|Doe v. Ashcroft]]. EFF files amicus supporting ACLU's challenge to the constitutionality of 18 U.S.C. § 2709, which authorizes the FBI to compel the production of subscriber and communications records in the possession of a broad range of ISPs, potentially covering billions of records from tens of thousands of entities. These demands, known as National Security Letters, were issued without judicial oversight of any kind, yet allowed the FBI to obtain a vast amount of constitutionally protected information. In September 2004, Judge Victor Marrero of the Southern District of New York issues a landmark decision striking down the NSL statute and the associated gag provision. *August 2004: ''[[Chamberlain v. Skylink]]''. EFF helps defend Skylink in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit|Federal Circuit]] that puts limits on the controversial "anti-circumvention" provision of the DMCA. Chamberlain, the manufacturer of garage doors, invoked the provision to stop Skylink from selling a "universal" remote control that works with Chamberlain garage doors. The court rejected Chamberlain's claims, noting that if it adopted the company's interpretation of the DMCA, it would threaten many legitimate uses of software within electronic and computer products — something the law aims to protect. *August 19, 2004: [https://web.archive.org/web/20081011114548/http://eff.org/IP/P2P/MGM_v_Grokster MGM v. Grokster]. EFF prevails before the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] with a decision affirming the "Betamax doctrine" — the rule following the Supreme Court's 1984 holding that a company that creates a technology cannot be held liable for copyright violations by users if the technology has substantial legal uses. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals rules that neither were liable for infringements by people using their software to distribute copyrighted works. However, on June 27, 2005 U.S. Supreme Court reverses, finding the defendants liable for copyright infringement, though the Court preserved the Betamax doctrine. Co-defendant Grokster eventually settles with MGM and disbands the company. *October 6, 2004: EFF submits a [https://www.eff.org/news/archives/2004_10.php#001968 brief] in cooperation with eight other public interest organizations, challenging the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC's]] authority to impose the [[broadcast flag]] mandate, which was to go into effect during July 2005. *October 15, 2004: EFF successfully represents the non-profit ISP Online Policy Group (OPG) and two Swarthmore College students who published major security flaws in Diebold Election Systems (now [[Premier Election Solutions]]) [[voting machine]]s. From the press release: "Diebold is the first company to be held liable for violating section 512(f) of the DMCA, which makes it unlawful to use DMCA takedown threats when the copyright holder knows that infringement has not actually occurred." *2004: ''[[JibJab Media v. Ludlow Music]]'', N.D. Cal. EFF successfully defends [[JibJab]], the creators of a parody flash animation piece using [[Woody Guthrie]]'s "[[This Land Is Your Land]]", and uncovered evidence that the classic folk song is in fact already part of the [[public domain]]. *November 2004: EFF files brief opposing the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC's]] proposal to expand [[Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act|CALEA]] to broadband Internet access providers and [[Voice over Internet Protocol|VoIP]] systems. *December 2004: EFF starts promoting and supporting [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]], a second generation Onion Routing network that allows people to communicate anonymously.
==2005–present== *June 2005: EFF issues a Legal Guide for Bloggers, designed to be a basic roadmap to the legal issues one may confront as a blogger, to let bloggers know their rights. *October 2005: EFF investigates and documents how the Xerox [[DocuColor]] printer's serial number, as well as the date and time of the printout, are encoded in a repeating 15 by 8 dot pattern in the yellow channel on printed pages. EFF is working to reverse engineer additional printers. (see [[Printer steganography]]) * November 2005: EFF files suit against [[Sony BMG]] — along with two leading national class action law firms — demanding that the company repair the damage done by [[Fortium Technologies]] (then ''First 4 Internet'')'s [[Extended Copy Protection|XCP]] and [[SunnComm]] [[MediaMax CD-3]] software it included on over 24 million music CDs (see [[2005 Sony BMG CD copy prevention scandal]]). * January 2006: ''[[Hepting v. AT&T]]''. EFF files a class action lawsuit against [[AT&T]] alleging that AT&T allowed the [[National Security Agency|NSA]] to potentially tap the entirety of its clients' Internet and Voice over IP communications. * August 2006: EFF files a complaint with the [[Federal Trade Commission]], accusing [[AOL]] of violating the [[Federal Trade Commission Act]] and asking for the FTC to take action. EFF alleges that AOL has engaged in deceptive and unfair trade practices with the disclosure of 20 million search queries of 650,000 anonymized users, intended for research purposes (see [[AOL#Search data release|AOL]] for details). AOL is failing to "implement reasonable and appropriate measures to protect personal consumer information from public disclosure." Beyond that, AOL's failure to "employ proper security measures ... to protect personal consumer information from public disclosure" constitutes an unfair trade practice. * November 2006: EFF files a lawsuit, on behalf of blogger Jeffrey Diehl, against Michael Crook, a webmaster Diehl claimed filed false DMCA claims against his and other websites.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/press/archives/2006/11/01 |date=November 1, 2006 |title=Craigslist Sex Ad Scammer Seeks to Silence Critics |publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation}}</ref> The case is settled in early 2007. * October 2007: The United States Patent and Trademark Office accepted the EFF’s request for the reexamination of NeoMedia's patent #6,199,048 that is alleged to threaten mobile information access.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/press/archives/2007/10/23 |title=EFF Wins Reexamination of Bogus Patent | Electronic Frontier Foundation |publisher=Eff.org |date=October 23, 2007 |accessdate=2008-12-02}}</ref> *May 2007 files ''[[Sapient v. Geller]]''<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.eff.org/legal/cases/sapient_v_geller/ | title=Sapient v. Geller Documents | publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation |date=2007-05-08 | first= | last= | accessdate = 2007-06-01}}</ref> *August 2008: ''[[United States v. Arnold]]'' *September 2008: ''[[Jewel v. NSA]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/cases/jewel |title=Jewel v. NSA | Electronic Frontier Foundation |publisher=Eff.org |date= |accessdate=2008-12-02}}</ref> *October 2008: ''[[Hepting v. AT&T]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/press/archives/2008/10/17 |title=EFF Challenges Constitutionality of Telecom Immunity in Federal Court | Electronic Frontier Foundation |publisher=Eff.org |date=October 17, 2008 |accessdate=2008-12-02}}</ref> *December 2010: Following the [[United States diplomatic cables leak]], the EFF offered support to [[WikiLeaks]], with [[John Perry Barlow]] saying the EFF was 'trying to make sure they have plenty of mirror sites, back-ups, we're organising donations for them and generally doing everything we can to see that Wikileaks is not assailable by the methods that have been used against it so far'.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2010/12/09/3089103.htm |title= Few American friends for Wikileaks |accessdate= 2010-12-09 |author= Simon Leo Brown, ABC News}}</ref> *June 2012: EFF started the [[Defend Innovation]] patent reform project.<ref>{{cite web|title=Defend Innovation|url=https://defendinnovation.org/|website=Defend Innovation|accessdate=13 December 2015}}</ref> *April 2015: EFF started the Fight215.org website to stop the [[mass surveillance]] enabled by [[Patriot Act]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New Coalition Site Fight215.org Launches to Amplify Opposition to the NSA’s Mass Surveillance|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2015/04/new-coalition-site-fight215org-launches-amplify-opposition-nsas-mass-surveillance|website=Electronic Frontier Foundation|accessdate=13 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stop the Patriot Act's Mass Surveillance|url=https://fight215.org/|website=Fight 215|accessdate=13 December 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
